docs.text: john carpenter makes b-movies .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: always has ( " halloween , " " escape from new york , " " the thing " ) and , by the looks of it ( " they live , " " escape from l . a . , " " vampires " ) , always will .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: carpenter's latest horror opus with a science fiction bent ( or science fiction outing with a schlock horror bent ) is the aptly-titled " john carpenter's ghosts of mars " ( in case , i suppose , you went looking for someone else's " ghosts of mars " ) .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: like all those films prefixed by the very possessive " john carpenter's , " " ghosts of mars " is an unashamed b-movie punctuated by a b-movie plot , b-movie actors , and b-movie special effects .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: in category one , above , we have a storyline that borders on idiotic ( and , at times , chaotic ) .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: dormant martians ( i . e . , swirling red gases ) awakened by meddling humans possess the souls of hapless mining colonists rendering them testy marilyn manson lookalikes .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: all this explained ( in flashback ) to some grand pooh-bah counsel by martian police official melanie ballard ( natasha henstridge , from the sub- " species " films ) , the only returnee on a silly-looking train .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: officer ballard went in to bring back incarcerated felon james " desolation " williams ; what she found was not a pretty picture .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: in the second category we have ms . henstridge , her blonde hair pulled back tightly and awkwardly into a ponytail , ice cube ( as the appropriately-named " desolation " ) , pam grier ( briefly , oddly--who wanted to work with whom i wonder ? ) , and a host of extras all assuming that the story and special effects were going to carry this film and therefore they didn't need to try too hard .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: in category number three we have , in addition to those swirling red gases and the silly-looking train , a couple of bird's-eye-view shots of a sprawling martian metropolis ( reddish also ) .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: state-of-the-art special effects have never been a carpenter trademark and once again the writer/director ( who seems to have no problem finding work , however ) doesn't waste any of the film's budget in that department .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: " ghosts of mars " is lock , laughing stock , and barrel all your standard carpenter fare : dingy interiors , cluttered exteriors , inane dialogue , lots of leather , scarred , crazed-looking aliens , and lots and lots of weaponry .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the film often and always explodes into warfare without warning--spontaneously , stupidly .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: carpenter might like to think he's made a western here but it's a western without any real heroes , villains , or border conflicts .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: it's just the shootouts minus a hissing snake plissken .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: i never thought i'd miss the guy but i do .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: it's not * all * the same , however .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: dubbed the " one-note wonder " for his minimalist music soundtracks , carpenter seems to have graduated from simplistic ( yet effective ) scoring by highlighting his action with loud , screeching guitar work .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: fortunately this drowns out a lot of the dialogue .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the final exchange between henstridge and , er , cube though is both audible * and * priceless .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: mars has proven an infertile breeding ground for hollywood in the last year or so , what with the stillborn " mission to mars " and " red planet " ( with val kilmer ) .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: " ghosts of mars " sadly adds to those disappointing returns ( in its opening weekend it was overshadowed by a bunch of sequels , among them " american pie 2 " and " rush hour 2 " ) .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the irony is that the mars in carpenter's film feels sadly absent .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: there are occasional references to the red planet , of course , but the film might as well have been set in perth amboys than on earth's closest neighbor .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: two things keep " john carpenter's ghosts of mars " from getting a huge slap upside the head .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: henstridge keeps her top on ( miraculously ) , and 2 . the film doesn't pretend to be anything it's not .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: what that means , however , is that fans of superior , intelligent , grade a sci-fi/horror are singularly out of luck .
docs.label: negative
